metadata.name: Learner Support
metadata.description: Types of support provided to learners to facilitate learning, engagement, and success. Covers motivational support, emotional support, cognitive support, social support, accessibility support, and feedback provision.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Types of support provided to learners to facilitate learning, engagement, and success

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Learner support ultimately aims to build learner independence

positive_examples: The tutor provided both cognitive and emotional support throughout the session.
Effective support addresses not just content confusion but also motivation and confidence.
Scaffolding, encouragement, and accessibility accommodations are all forms of learner support.
Good tutoring means meeting learners where they are and providing what they need to progress.
negative_examples: The lecture covered the required material.
The textbook was assigned for homework.
The classroom had adequate lighting.
training_hints.disambiguation: Active support for learners, not just content delivery

candidates.definition: Fostering learner engagement, interest, and persistence through relevance, autonomy, and encouragement

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Motivational support develops intrinsic motivation and learner agency

positive_examples: Let me show you why this skill matters for the career you're interested in.
You have some choice in which problems to work on - pick what interests you.
I can see you're making real progress - that persistence is paying off.
Connecting the material to students' genuine interests and goals.
negative_examples: Just memorize this because it's on the test.
You don't need to understand why, just do what I say.
If you don't finish, you'll fail the class.
training_hints.disambiguation: Building intrinsic motivation, not compliance through rewards or threats

candidates.definition: Addressing learner feelings, building confidence, reducing anxiety, and creating psychological safety

positive_examples: It's completely normal to feel confused at this stage - that's part of learning.
Let's take a break if you're feeling frustrated. We can approach this differently.
Mistakes are safe here - they're how we learn.
I can tell you're anxious about this. What would help you feel more comfortable?
negative_examples: Stop being so emotional and just focus.
Everyone else understands this - what's wrong with you?
There's no time to deal with feelings, we have material to cover.
training_hints.disambiguation: Addressing emotions and psychological safety, not ignoring affect

candidates.definition: Providing scaffolding, clarification, and strategies to help learners process and understand content

positive_examples: Let me break that down into smaller steps.
Here's a strategy that might help: try working backwards from the answer.
Can I give you a hint? Think about how this connects to what we learned last week.
Let me rephrase that explanation using an analogy.
negative_examples: Figure it out yourself.
I already explained it once - weren't you listening?
Here's the answer, let's move on.
training_hints.disambiguation: Supporting thinking and understanding, not just giving answers

candidates.definition: Facilitating peer connections, collaboration, and sense of belonging in learning communities
candidates.definition_source: Social learning theory, community of practice research

positive_examples: Let's pair you with someone who recently mastered this concept.
You're not alone in finding this challenging - many students struggle here.
Working with a study partner can help you both understand the material better.
The learning community provides support that extends beyond one-on-one tutoring.
negative_examples: Don't talk to other students - this is individual work.
Comparing yourself to others is pointless.
Learning is a solitary endeavor.
training_hints.disambiguation: Building connections and community, not isolation

candidates.definition: Providing accommodations and removing barriers to ensure all learners can access and engage with content
candidates.definition_source: Universal Design for Learning, accessibility research

positive_examples: The materials are available in audio format for students with visual impairments.
Extended time accommodations level the playing field, not provide unfair advantage.
Multiple means of representation ensure diverse learners can access content.
Let's find a format that works for how you learn best.
negative_examples: Everyone has to learn the same way.
If you can't keep up with the standard approach, that's your problem.
Accommodations give some students an unfair advantage.
training_hints.disambiguation: Removing barriers to access, not lowering standards

candidates.definition: Providing timely, specific, actionable information about performance to guide improvement

positive_examples: Your thesis is clear, but the evidence in paragraph 3 doesn't support it. Try finding a quote that...
You're applying the formula correctly, but check your arithmetic in step 2.
Effective feedback tells students where they are, where they're going, and how to get there.
Specific, actionable feedback that students can use to improve.
negative_examples: Good job!
This is wrong.
Try harder next time.
B-
training_hints.disambiguation: Specific actionable guidance, not vague praise or criticism
